awd_titl_txt: Operations and Maintenance of the Arecibo Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
To enable a world-wide multi-user community to realize research and education programs, the University of Central Florida (UCF) presents a strategic vision over the next five years to manage, operate, and disseminate results from the unique capabilities of the Arecibo Observatory (AO).  AO will provide observations, and support researchers, in three main areas:  Radio Astronomy, Atmospheric Sciences, and Planetary Radar. The management team includes members with expertise in the science at AO, in maintenance and operations, and in education and public outreach.

Under UCF management, AO will allow researchers to make innovative use of the facility, and maintain its central role in science and education into the future. For example, the role of AO in the detection and characterization of Gravitational Waves is an exciting new opportunity.  The management team will search for other collaborators and funders interested in using the unique capabilities of AO (for example, its reflector sensitivity and location). The PIs will implement a New Business Development Team focused on developing other funding sources including donations, tourism and commercial clients. 

UCF balances science with the maintenance that assures the viability of AO for the long term. The management team plans to grow the diversity of science and maintain observations without trading off the condition of the facilities/equipment or a reduction in workforce. The goal is to maintain the total funding at the 2017/2018 level through government and non-government funding sources.  

AO continues to be a source of intellectual inspiration to the next generation of scientist, particularly those located in Puerto Rico. Under UCF management, AO will enable research by student scientists in Puerto Rico that will result in the next generation of Astronomers and Atmospheric Scientists. In addition, AO will provide workshops emphasizing STEAM education, create a summer research academy for high school students, and train a large number of STEAM high school teachers each year. Team member UMET, leading collaborations with the Puerto Rico Space Grant Consortium, expects to expand delivery of high quality student and teacher education programs using AO as a hub. An expected result is a pipeline of potential students and postdocs to support the science investigation interests of both UCF and Universities across Puerto Rico. The outreach plan updates the Angel Ramos Foundation Visitor Center, expanding the visitor experience at AO.

por.por_cntn:
From 2018 to 2023, the Management and Operations of the Arecibo Observatory under the leadership of the University of Central Florida and its partners, Universidad Ana G. Mendez, Cupey Campus, in charge of the educational and outreach component, and Yang Enterprises Inc., in charge of the facilities and operations, demonstrates a consistent commitment to advancing scientific research, operational excellence, and community engagement.

 

Throughout these years, the project has made: 1. Significant scientific discoveries and advancements in the areas of astronomy, planetary, space and atmospheric sciences. Examples include an all-time record of asteroid detection and characterization in planetary radar, the characterization of repeating FRB 20220912A in radio astronomy, the first time use of the Arecibo 12m telescope for solar studies in heliophysics, and the detection of signatures of lightning in the lower ionosphere using ISR in atmospheric sciences. In addition, the project contributed to the development and deployment of new instruments and methodologies that have broadened the scope and depth of research capabilities: among others, we established a Remote Optical Facility in the island of Culebra, Puerto Rico; upgraded the 12 m telescope; archived the AO data at TACC; and published 197 scientific publications; 2. The Facilities and Operations team implemented operational improvements that enhanced the efficiency and sustainability of the site’s infrastructure including upgrades to facilities, the introduction of more effective management practices, and the adoption of new technologies to support research activities; 3. Expanded its community engagement and educational outreach efforts, reaching a wider audience and inspiring the next generation of scientists. Initiatives have included public lectures, school visits, workshops, and participation in science festivals, which have not only increased public awareness of the project's work but also encouraged interest in STEM fields, impacting more than 186,000 students, teachers and the general public; 4. Faced and overcame a number of exceptional challenges, from several natural disasters to funding uncertainties, demonstrating resilience and adaptability. The project's response to these challenges has included mobilizing resources for recovery efforts, adapting research and operational plans, and fostering partnerships to ensure continuity and support; 5. Implemented strategic goals for the future, focusing on expanding its research portfolio, securing sustainable funding sources, and enhancing the Observatory’s role as a leader in scientific education and outreach. The project leveraged its achievements exploring new research frontiers, fostering innovation, and contributed to solving some of the most pressing scientific questions of our time and the uncertainty of the future of the scientific facility due to the collapse of the main instrument.

 

The closure of the Arecibo Observatory phase marked a significant transition of the facility, emphasizing safety, data preservation, and environmental stewardship. The Closeout Plan was meticulously executed, showcasing resilience, efficiency in managing decommissioning tasks, and dedication to preserving the legacy through scientific data archiving and educational outreach. Significant achievements in this phase included the successful archival of decades of scientific data, technological advancements in safely decommissioning instruments, and impactful education and public outreach efforts. This period underscored the lasting contribution of the Arecibo Observatory to scientific discovery with more than 300 scientific publications using Arecibo, technical innovation, and community engagement, concluding a notable chapter in astronomical, planetary and atmospheric sciences research while ensuring the Observatory's legacy to continue inspiring future generations.

 

In summary, the project has made substantial contributions to its field, impacting both the scientific community and the broader public. Its efforts to advance knowledge, engage with diverse audiences, and navigate challenges reflect a dynamic and forward-looking approach, positioning it well for continued success in the years ahead with NSF’s new vision for the facility as an Educational Center.
